title: Design: Collapse mail into beads
description:
## Proposal

Replace the separate mail system (JSONL inboxes) with beads issues using a naming convention.

## Rationale

If all state should be in beads (work items, swarm state, dependencies), why have a separate system for messages? Mail is just:
- Handoffs (agent ‚Üí self)
- Commands (Mayor ‚Üí Refinery)
- Escalations (Witness ‚Üí Mayor)

These can all be beads issues with a special prefix.

## Design

### Convention
- Messages use `@-` prefix: `@-witness-1734012345`
- Assignee = recipient
- Status: open = unread, closed = read/acknowledged
- Priority 0 = urgent

### Commands (thin wrappers)
```bash
gt mail send witness -s "Subject" -m "Body"
  ‚Üí bd create --prefix=@ --title="Subject" --assignee=witness --description="Body"

gt mail inbox
  ‚Üí bd list --prefix=@ --assignee=$(gt whoami) --status=open

gt mail read @-abc
  ‚Üí bd show @-abc && bd close @-abc
```

### Notification
Daemon watches for new `@-` issues and pokes relevant sessions.
Or: agents poll on heartbeat (simpler).

## What We Remove
- `mail/inbox.jsonl` files
- Mail JSONL read/write code
- Separate delivery mechanism

## What We Keep
- `gt mail` CLI (as wrapper)
- Handoff semantics
- Notification (via daemon or polling)

## Benefits
- One system, one sync, one query interface
- All communication in git history
- Simpler architecture

## Risks
- Beads prefix filtering must be efficient
- Namespace collision with user prefixes
- Performance for high-frequency messages (probably fine for handoffs)

## Decision Point
Do we need first-class mail support in beads (`bd mail` commands) or is convention sufficient?

title: Document Overseer role (human operator)
description:
Document the Overseer role in Gas Town architecture.

## The Overseer

The **Overseer** is the human operator of Gas Town. Not an agent - a person.

## Responsibilities

| Area | Overseer Does | Mayor/Agents Do |
|------|---------------|-----------------|
| Strategy | Define project goals | Execute toward goals |
| Priorities | Set priority order | Work in priority order |
| Escalations | Final decision on stuck work | Escalate to Overseer |
| Resources | Provision machines | Use allocated resources |
| Quality | Review & approve swarm output | Produce output |
| Operations | Run gt commands, monitor dashboards | Do the work |

## Key Interactions

### Overseer ‚Üí Mayor
- Start/stop Mayor sessions
- Direct Mayor via conversation
- Review Mayor recommendations
- Approve cross-rig decisions

### Mayor ‚Üí Overseer (Escalations)
- Stuck workers after retries
- Resource decisions (add machines, polecats)
- Ambiguous requirements
- Architecture decisions

## Operating Cadence

Typical Overseer workflow:
1. Morning: Check status, review overnight work
2. During day: Monitor, respond to escalations, adjust priorities
3. End of day: Review progress, plan next batch

## Commands for Overseers

```bash
gt status              # Quick health check
gt doctor              # Detailed diagnostics  
gt doctor --fix        # Auto-repair issues
gt inbox               # Messages from agents
gt stop --all          # Emergency halt
```

## Documentation Updates

Add to docs/architecture.md:
- Overseer section under Agent Roles
- Clarify Mayor reports to Overseer
- Add Overseer to workflow diagrams

title: Doctor check: Zombie session cleanup
description:
Detect and clean up zombie tmux sessions via gt doctor.

## Problem

Zombie sessions occur when:
- Agent crashes without cleanup
- gt kill fails mid-operation
- System restart leaves orphan sessions
- Session naming collision

## Checks

### ZombieSessionCheck
- List all tmux sessions matching gt-* pattern
- Cross-reference with known polecats
- Flag sessions with no corresponding polecat state
- Flag sessions for removed polecats
- Check session age vs polecat creation time

### Detection Criteria
- Session exists but polecat directory doesn't
- Session name doesn't match any registered polecat
- Polecat state=idle but session running
- Multiple sessions for same polecat

## Output

```
[WARN] Zombie tmux sessions detected:
  - gt-wyvern-OldPolecat (polecat removed)
  - gt-beads-Unknown (no matching polecat)
  - gt-wyvern-Toast (duplicate session)

  Run 'gt doctor --fix' to clean up
```

## Auto-Fix (--fix flag)

- Kill orphan tmux sessions
- Update polecat state to match reality
- Log all cleanup actions

## Safety

- Never kill sessions where polecat state=working
- Prompt before killing if --fix used without --force
- Create audit log of killed sessions

title: Interactive prompts for destructive operations
description:
Add interactive confirmations for destructive operations.

## Operations Needing Confirmation
- `gt swarm cancel` - Cancels active swarm
- `gt swarm land --force` - Force landing
- `gt polecat decommission` - Removes polecat
- `gt rig remove` - Removes rig
- `gt stop --all` - Stops all sessions
- `gt mail purge` - Permanently deletes mail

## Implementation Options

### Option 1: promptui library
```go
import "github.com/manifoldco/promptui"

prompt := promptui.Prompt{
    Label:     "Delete polecat Toast",
    IsConfirm: true,
}
result, err := prompt.Run()
```

### Option 2: Simple stdin
```go
func confirm(prompt string) bool {
    fmt.Printf("%s [y/N]: ", prompt)
    var response string
    fmt.Scanln(&response)
    return strings.ToLower(response) == "y"
}
```

## Bypass Flags
All confirmations skippable with --force or --yes:
```go
if !force && !confirm("Really cancel swarm?") {
    return nil
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Destructive ops prompt by default
- [ ] --force or --yes bypasses
- [ ] Clear prompt text explaining action
- [ ] Non-interactive mode (piped input) auto-fails

title: mol-polecat-lease
description:
Semaphore tracking a single polecat's lifecycle.
Vars: {{polecat}}, {{issue}}

Used by Witness to track polecat lifecycle during patrol. The Witness bonds
this proto for each active polecat, creating a lease that tracks the polecat
from spawn through work to cleanup.

## Step: boot
Spawned. Verify it starts working.

Check if the polecat is alive and working:
```bash
gt peek {{polecat}}
```

If idle for too long, nudge:
```bash
gt nudge {{polecat}} "Please start working on your assigned issue."
```

Timeout: 60s before escalation to Mayor.

## Step: working
Actively working. Monitor for stuck.

The polecat is processing its assigned issue ({{issue}}).
Monitor via peek. Watch for:
- Progress on commits
- Status updates in beads
- SHUTDOWN mail when done

Wait for SHUTDOWN signal from the polecat.
Needs: boot

## Step: done
Exit received. Ready for cleanup.

The polecat has completed its work and sent SHUTDOWN.
Perform cleanup:
```bash
gt session kill {{polecat}}
gt worktree prune {{polecat}}
```

Update beads state and close the lease.
Needs: working

title: Plugin surface for daemon lifecycle hooks
description:
Allow rigs to customize daemon behavior via hooks/plugins.

## Hook Points

- on_heartbeat: Called during daemon heartbeat cycle
- on_worker_idle: Called when worker goes idle
- on_worker_stuck: Called when stuck detection triggers
- on_lifecycle_request: Called before processing lifecycle

## Configuration

```
<rig>/config/daemon-hooks.json
{
  "on_heartbeat": "./hooks/check-ci-status.sh",
  "on_worker_idle": "./hooks/maybe-assign-work.sh",
  "idle_threshold": "5m",
  "custom_signals": [
    {"name": "ci_status", "command": "./hooks/get-ci.sh"}
  ]
}
```

## Signal Contribution

Hooks can return signals that feed into decision engine:
- SKIP_POKE: Don't poke this agent
- FORCE_POKE: Override backoff, poke now
- CUSTOM_DATA: Extra context for logging

## Use Cases

title: gt mail inbox doesn't find crew worker mail - identity mismatch
description:
## Problem

Crew workers don't see their handoff messages when running `gt mail inbox` from their working directory.

## Root Cause

gt derives identity from cwd path, but crew workers have a different path structure:
- **cwd**: `/Users/stevey/gt/beads/crew/dave`
- **gt derives**: `beads/crew/dave` (wrong)
- **should be**: `beads/dave` (crew workers use `rig/name` format)

Messages sent to `beads/dave` don't show up because gt is looking for `beads/crew/dave`.

## Workaround

Use explicit identity flag:
```bash
gt mail inbox --identity "beads/dave"
```

## Fix

Identity detection in gt should handle crew/ subdirectory:
- Path `<rig>/crew/<name>` should derive identity as `<rig>/<name>`
- This matches how polecats work: `<rig>/polecats/<name>` ‚Üí `<rig>/<name>`

## Affected

All crew workers in all rigs.

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---

title: Mail orchestrator daemon
description:
Background mail orchestrator daemon.

## Command
```
gt mail orchestrate [--interval N] [--once] [--verbose]
```

## Purpose
Background process that:
1. Monitors outbox for pending mail
2. Delivers to recipient inboxes
3. Handles offline recipients (retry later)
4. Cleans delivered messages from outbox

## Why Needed?
Current mail is synchronous. If recipient is offline or mailbox locked, send fails.
Orchestrator enables async delivery with retry.

## Implementation
```go
func (o *Orchestrator) Run(interval time.Duration) error {
    ticker := time.NewTicker(interval)
    for range ticker.C {
        o.processOutbox()
    }
}

func (o *Orchestrator) processOutbox() {
    // List outbox/*.json
    // For each, attempt delivery
    // On success, delete from outbox
    // On failure, increment retry count
}
```

## Outbox Structure
```
<town>/mayor/mail/outbox/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ msg-abc123.json
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ msg-def456.json
```

## Lower Priority
Current synchronous delivery works. Orchestrator is optimization.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Background daemon mode
- [ ] Retry failed deliveries
- [ ] --once for single pass
- [ ] Configurable interval

title: Epic: Wisp Molecule Integration
description:
## Vision

Integrate Beads wisp molecules into Gas Town. All orchestration work runs as wisp molecules - patrols, polecat workflows, batch operations. Only digests reach main beads.

## The Steam Engine Metaphor

```
Engine does work ‚Üí generates steam
Steam wisps rise ‚Üí execution trace
Steam condenses ‚Üí digest (distillate)  
Steam dissipates ‚Üí cleaned up (burned)
```

## Architecture

```
Proto Molecules (templates)
    ‚Üì bd mol bond
Wisps (.beads-wisps/ or inline)
    ‚Üì bd mol squash + AI summary
Main Beads (digests only)
```

## Vocabulary

| Term | Meaning |
|------|---------|
| bond | Attach proto to work (creates wisps) |
| wisp | Temporary execution step (steam rising) |
| squash | Condense wisps into digest |
| burn | Destroy wisps without record |
| digest | Permanent condensed record (distillate) |

## Key Design Decisions

1. **Wisp location**: Per-rig or inline in main beads with wisp flag
2. **Summary generation**: Agent that did work generates summary (inversion of control)
3. **Squash timing**: Final step of molecule workflow, before signaling done
4. **Crash recovery**: Wisps persist, Witness detects stalls, new agent resumes
5. **Patrols**: Each cycle is fresh wisp molecule, squashed on completion

## Digest Contents

- Molecule type and instance ID
- Assignee, start/end times
- Source issue reference
- AI-generated summary
- Outcomes (issues closed, commits, branches)

## Integration Points

- gt rig init: Configure wisp storage
- gt spawn --molecule: Bond creates wisps
- gt prime: Show wisp molecule context
- Polecat CLAUDE.md: Summary + squash protocol
- gt doctor: Wisp health checks
- Deacon/Witness/Refinery: Patrol molecules

## Phases

Phase 1: Wisp setup infrastructure
Phase 2: Spawn integration
Phase 3: Completion flow (summary + squash)
Phase 4: Patrol integration
Phase 5: Documentation and polish

  b. Reassign to new agent
  c. Escalate to Mayor

### Squash fails
- Retry with exponential backoff
- If persistent failure, escalate
- Don't lose the ephemeral state until squash succeeds

### Orphaned molecules
- Molecule started, never completed
- gt doctor detects (>24h old with no activity)
- Options:
  a. Manual review
  b. Auto-abandon with 'abandoned' digest
  c. Reassign

### Ephemeral repo corruption
- Re-init from scratch
- Active molecules are lost
- Main beads is source of truth for assigned work

## Implementation

- bd mol bond (handle init failures)
- bd squash (retry logic)
- gt doctor (recovery suggestions)

title: Engineer main loop: poll for ready merge-requests

| **Handoff mail** | Context notes for restart | `gt mail read` (self-addressed) |

The molecule is **the actual work** - required state.

Gas Town has custom attachment system:

- Separate from beads pinning

# This: spawns, assigns to caller, pins root, sets in_progress
```

```bash

```

- Remove handoff bead attachment docs

## Problem

When resetting or landing a rig/town, stale mail messages can confuse agents on startup. Old handoff messages, daemon notifications, and inter-agent mail should be cleaned up as part of reset.

- `gt rig reset` exists but doesn't clear mail
- Stale messages accumulate (e.g., daemon SHUTDOWN messages)

## Proposed Behavior

`gt rig reset` and `gt town reset` should:
1. Close all open messages (`--type=message`) in the relevant beads
2. Optionally preserve pinned handoff beads (clear content, keep bead)
3. Log what was cleaned up

```bash
gt rig reset gastown          # Clears gastown mail
gt rig reset gastown --mail   # Only clear mail, keep other state
gt town reset                 # Clears all town-level mail
gt town reset --all           # Clears mail in all rigs too
```

## Implementation

1. Query `bd list --type=message --status=open`
2. Close each with reason 'Cleared during reset'
3. For pinned handoffs: `bd update <id> --description=''` instead of close

title: Molecules: Composable Workflow Beads
description:
## Summary

Molecules are crystallized workflow patterns stored as Beads issues.
When instantiated, the molecule creates child beads forming a DAG.

## Key Insight: Molecules ARE Beads

Per HOP Decision 001: Beads IS the ledger. Molecules don't get a separate YAML format - they're issues with `type: molecule` containing prose-based step definitions.

Agents don't need rigid schemas. They parse natural language natively. A molecule is just instructions with enough structure for tooling.

## Example: Engineer in a Box

```markdown
id: mol-xyz
type: molecule
title: Engineer in a Box

This workflow takes a task from design to merge.

## Step: design
Think carefully about architecture. Consider existing patterns, 
trade-offs, testability.

## Step: implement
Write clean code. Follow codebase conventions.
Needs: design

## Step: review  
Review for bugs, edge cases, style issues.
Needs: implement

## Step: test
Write and run tests. Cover happy path and edge cases.
Needs: implement

## Step: submit
Submit for merge via refinery.
Needs: review, test
```

## Instantiation

```bash
# Attach molecule when spawning
gt spawn --issue gt-abc --molecule mol-xyz

# Creates child beads atomically:
gt-abc.design     ‚Üê ready first
gt-abc.implement  ‚Üê blocked by design  
gt-abc.review     ‚Üê blocked by implement
gt-abc.test       ‚Üê blocked by implement
gt-abc.submit     ‚Üê blocked by review, test
```

Each step issue gets an `instantiated-from` edge to the molecule (with step metadata).

## Why This Matters

1. **Unified data plane**: Everything in Beads, no parallel YAML channel
2. **AI-native**: Prose instructions, not rigid schemas
3. **Error isolation**: Each step is a checkpoint - failure doesn't lose progress
4. **Scales with AI**: As agents get smarter, they handle more complex molecules

## Implementation Primitives

- `ParseMoleculeSteps()`: Extract steps from prose (convention-based)
- `InstantiateMolecule()`: Atomic transaction creating all steps + edges  
- `instantiated-from` edge type: Track provenance
- Parameterization: `{{variable}}` substitution from context map

title: Molecule schema: YAML format for workflow definitions
description:

molecule: <name>
version: 1
description: "Human description"
steps:
  - id: <step-id>
    title: "Step title"
    prompt: "Instructions for agent"
    depends: [<other-step-ids>]  # optional
    tier: haiku|sonnet|opus      # optional, default from config
    timeout: 30m                 # optional
```

Store molecules in:
- `<rig>/molecules/<name>.yaml` for rig-specific
- `<town>/molecules/<name>.yaml` for town-wide

Built-in molecules to ship:
- engineer-in-box: design‚Üícode‚Üíreview‚Üítest‚Üísubmit
- quick-fix: implement‚Üítest‚Üísubmit
- research: investigate‚Üídocument

title: Molecule instantiation: create child beads from template
description:
When instantiating a molecule on a work bead:

## Transaction Flow

1. Parse molecule's `## Step:` sections from description
2. Begin SQLite transaction
3. For each step, create child issue:
   - ID: `{parent-id}.{step-ref}` or generated
   - Title: step title (from header or first line)
   - Description: step prose instructions
   - Type: task
   - Priority: inherit from parent
4. Add `instantiated-from` edge from each step to molecule:
   ```sql
   INSERT INTO dependencies (issue_id, depends_on_id, type, metadata)
   VALUES (step_id, mol_id, 'instantiated-from', '{"step": "implement"}');
   ```
5. Wire inter-step dependencies from `Needs:` lines
6. Commit transaction (atomic - all or nothing)

## Parsing Conventions

```markdown
## Step: <ref>
<prose instructions>
Needs: <step>, <step>  # optional
Tier: haiku|sonnet|opus  # optional hint
```

## Parameterization

Steps can have `{{variable}}` placeholders:
```markdown
## Step: implement
Implement {{feature_name}} in {{target_file}}.
```

Context map provided at instantiation time.

## API

```go
func (s *Store) InstantiateMolecule(mol *Issue, parent *Issue, ctx map[string]string) ([]*Issue, error)
func ParseMoleculeSteps(description string) ([]MoleculeStep, error)
```

Implementation lives in `internal/beads/molecule.go`.

title: Convert MR queue to wisp storage
description:
MR queue should use wisp storage (.beads-wisp/) instead of durable beads.

## Design (Simplified)

With refinery as worktree, polecats and refinery share the same machine. No cross-machine MR coordination needed. Wisps are the natural fit.

### Storage
- Location: `.beads-wisp/mq/<mr-id>.json`
- Format: Same MRFields structure (branch, target, source_issue, worker, rig)
- Lifecycle: Create on submit, delete after merge

### Code Changes

1. **MR Creation** (done.go, mq_submit.go)
   - Write to `.beads-wisp/mq/` instead of `bd create --type=merge-request`
   - Generate ID: `mr-<timestamp>-<random>` or similar

2. **Refinery Query** (refinery/manager.go, engineer.go)
   - Read from `.beads-wisp/mq/` directory
   - List files, parse JSON, process in order

3. **Cleanup**
   - Delete MR file after successful merge
   - On failure, leave file (refinery retries)

### What Stays in Beads
- Source issues (the work being merged) - still tracked in beads
- Merge commits reference source issue ID
- `bd close <issue>` still happens on merge

### Benefits
- No sync overhead for transient MR state
- Simpler model (file per MR, delete when done)
- Consistent with wisp philosophy (ephemeral operational state)

### Not Needed
- Digest squashing (MRs are deleted, not accumulated)
- Cross-machine visibility (single-machine architecture)

title: Witness MVP: Automated Polecat Lifecycle
description:
Implement the Witness agent - per-rig 'pit boss' that manages polecat lifecycles.

The Witness enables hands-free swarming by automating:
- Spawning polecats for ready work
- Monitoring worker health
- Processing shutdown requests  
- Cleaning up worktrees when done
- Escalating stuck workers to Mayor

Without Witness, humans must manually spawn, monitor, and kill each polecat.

## Core Loop

```
while True:
  # Handle pending shutdowns
  for polecat in polecats where state == pending_shutdown:
    verify git clean
    kill session  
    remove worktree
    delete branch
    
  # Spawn for ready work
  ready = bd ready --parent=<epic> if epic else bd ready
  for issue in ready:
    if active_workers < max_workers:
      gt spawn --issue <id>
      
  # Check worker health
  for polecat in active polecats:
    if stuck (no progress for 30 min):
      nudge or escalate
      
  sleep 60
```

## Blocking Bugs to Fix
- gt-dsfi: handoff deadlock
- gt-n7z7: refinery foreground race condition
- gm-c6b: mail coordination (town vs rig beads)

title: Deacon: Hierarchical health-check orchestrator
description:
Replace daemon heartbeats with Deacon - an AI agent that keeps Gas Town running.

## Core Concept

The Deacon is a **Claude agent** (not just a Go process) that:
- Lives at town root in gt-deacon session
- Has its own mailbox (deacon/ identity in town beads)
- Is poked by a minimal Go daemon every ~60s (if idle)
- Monitors Mayor and Witnesses proactively
- Handles lifecycle requests (restart/cycle) from Mayor, Witnesses, AND Crew

## Architecture

```
Minimal Go Daemon (just watches Deacon)
         |
         v
     Deacon (Claude agent)
         |
    +----+----+
    v         v
  Mayor    Witnesses --> Polecats (Witness-managed)
    |         |
    +----+----+
         |
      Crew (lifecycle only, not monitored)
```

## Deacon Responsibilities

**Proactive monitoring:**
- Mayor health (tmux session, keepalive freshness)
- Witness health (tmux sessions, keepalive freshness)

**Reactive lifecycle:**
- Process restart/cycle requests from Mayor, Witnesses, Crew
- Kill session, create new, prime, verify startup

**Escalation:**
- Mail human (configurable) if issues can't be resolved

## Key Files

- ~/gt/DEACON.md - Role context
- ~/gt/deacon/ - State directory
  - heartbeat.json - Written each wake cycle (daemon checks this)
  - state.json - Health tracking, last scan results
- ~/gt/.beads/ - Town beads with deacon/ mail identity

## Wake Cycle

1. Write heartbeat (prevents daemon from poking)
2. Check mail (lifecycle requests)
3. Quick health scan (Mayor, Witnesses)
4. Process lifecycle requests
5. Remediate unhealthy agents
6. Update state

## Session Patterns

- Deacon: gt-deacon
- Mayor: gt-mayor
- Witness: gt-<rig>-witness
- Crew: gt-<rig>-<name> (e.g., gt-gastown-max)

## Relation to Policy Beads

Future: Deacon behavior configurable via policy beads (gt-3zw).
Initial implementation uses sensible defaults.

title: Deacon primes pending workers instead of spawn nudge
description:
## Problem

When gt spawn starts a polecat, it tries to send a nudge message immediately:
1. Starts tmux session with Claude Code
2. Waits 3 seconds (hardcoded)
3. Sends nudge via NudgeSession

But Claude Code takes 10-20+ seconds to be ready. The message arrives before
the prompt is ready, so it appears as part of the prompt string instead of
being executed.

## Solution

Move priming responsibility to the Deacon patrol cycle:

1. gt spawn: Mark polecat as pending_prime=true in state, return immediately
2. Deacon patrol: New step prime-pending-workers that:
   - Scans all rigs for workers with pending_prime=true
   - Uses WaitForClaudeReady() to poll for "> " prompt (already exists in tmux.go)
   - Once ready, sends gt prime + assignment nudge
   - Clears pending_prime flag

## Implementation

### spawn.go changes
- Remove the 3-second sleep (line 368)
- Remove the NudgeSession call (lines 375-383)
- Instead: Update polecat state with pending_prime=true

### Polecat state addition
status: assigned, pending_prime: true, issue: gt-xxx

### Deacon patrol addition
Add step between inbox-check and plugin-run:
prime-pending-workers: Check all rigs for workers marked pending_prime.
For each pending worker: WaitForClaudeReady(60s), then gt prime + nudge

### Benefits
- No race condition - we poll until actually ready
- Deacon already does health checks - priming is natural fit
- Works for polecats, witnesses, refineries, crew (unified approach)
- Timeout handling built in

## Depends on
- Existing WaitForClaudeReady() in tmux.go (lines 384-403)

title: Hook system for event extensibility
description:
GGT needs hook system for extensibility like PGT.

## Event Types
```go
type Event string
const (
    EventPreSessionStart  Event = "pre-session-start"
    EventPostSessionStart Event = "post-session-start"
    EventPreShutdown      Event = "pre-shutdown"
    EventPostShutdown     Event = "post-shutdown"
    EventOnPaneOutput     Event = "on-pane-output"
    EventSessionIdle      Event = "session-idle"
    EventMailReceived     Event = "mail-received"
    EventWorkAssigned     Event = "work-assigned"
)
```

## Hook Configuration
File: .claude/hooks.json or .gastown/hooks.json
```json
{
  "hooks": {
    "pre-shutdown": [
      {"type": "command", "cmd": "./scripts/pre-shutdown.sh"}
    ],
    "on-pane-output": [
      {"type": "command", "cmd": "./scripts/activity-monitor.sh"}
    ]
  }
}
```

## Hook Types
1. **Command**: Execute external script
2. **Built-in**: Internal Go functions (pre-shutdown checks)

## Hook Interface
```go
type HookRunner struct {
    config *HookConfig
}

type HookResult struct {
    Success bool
    Message string
    Block   bool  // For pre-* hooks: should operation be blocked?
}

func (r *HookRunner) Fire(event Event, ctx *HookContext) []HookResult
```

## CLI Commands
```
gt hooks list [<event>]    # List registered hooks
gt hooks fire <event>      # Manually fire for testing
gt hooks test [--all]      # Validate hook config
```

## Integration Points
- internal/session/manager.go: Fire pre/post session hooks
- internal/mail/router.go: Fire mail-received hook

## New Package
internal/hooks/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ types.go    # Event, HookConfig, HookResult
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ runner.go   # HookRunner, Fire()
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ builtin.go  # Built-in hooks (pre-shutdown checks)

title: Patrols: Cyclic molecules for autonomous maintenance
description:
## Vision

Patrols are **cyclic molecules** - workflow loops that give Gas Town its autonomous nervous system. While regular molecules are DAGs that terminate, patrols loop forever, performing maintenance tasks at varying cadences.

This is the "steam engine" of Gas Town: converting episodic Claude sessions into continuous autonomous operation.

## Core Concepts

### 1. Cyclic Molecules

Regular molecule:     A -> B -> C -> done
Patrol molecule:      A -> B -> C --+
                      ^             |
                      +-------------+

Patrols have a loop_to field specifying where to restart.

### 2. Cooldown-Aware Steps (Atoms)

Steps encode their own cadence. When patrol reaches a step:
1. Check: now - last_run > cooldown?
2. If yes: execute, update last_run
3. If no: skip (immediately close)

The patrol runner is simple - steps self-skip. Complexity distributed into atoms.

### 3. The Beacon

The heartbeat that fires patrol triggers:
- Internal ticker in Deacon (goroutine)
- Or external cron firing gt deacon tick
- Or mail-based triggers

Without beacon, nothing proactive happens.

### 4. Session Reset as Patrol Step

Connects to auto-handoff (gt-bcwn). Session reset is a patrol step, not a separate mechanism.

### 5. Multi-Role Patrols

Each supervisor has its own patrol:

**Deacon patrol:** health-check (30s), session-gc (5m), beacon-tick (10s)
**Witness patrol:** orphan-scan (10m), stuck-check (2m), molecule-progress (1m)
**Refinery patrol:** queue-check (30s), pr-status (1m), merge-ready (30s)

### 6. Cadence Tiers

- Critical (10-30s): Health checks
- Active (1-5m): Progress, nudges
- Maintenance (10-30m): Orphans, GC
- Periodic (1h+): Reports

### 7. Best-Effort Scheduling

Not real-time - more like cron. No hard deadlines. Catch-up, dont pile-up.
Priority preemption (mail interrupts patrol). Graceful degradation under load.

## Open Questions

1. State persistence: Beads (self-describing) or file (faster)?

## Metaphor

Claude was fire. Claude Code was steam. Gas Town is the steam engine. Beads is the train tracks.

The steam engine converts episodic combustion into continuous rotary motion.
Gas Town converts episodic Claude sessions into continuous autonomous work.

title: Fix failing beads tests: TestIntegration and TestPolecatWorkMolecule
Create mol-refinery-patrol with test failure gates
description:
## Problem

The Refinery role lacks:
1. A formal patrol molecule (Deacon has mol-deacon-patrol)
2. Engineer identity/philosophy guidance
3. Structural enforcement of failure handling (not just documentation)

When tests fail during merge processing, the current guidance doesn't prevent 'disavowal' - noting a problem exists and proceeding without tracking it.

## The Structural Solution

Create `mol-refinery-patrol` with **verification gates** that make disavowal structurally impossible:

```markdown
## Molecule: mol-refinery-patrol

## Step: inbox-check
Check mail for MR submissions, escalations, messages.
Process any urgent items first.

## Step: queue-scan
Fetch remote, identify polecat branches waiting.
If queue empty, skip to context-check.
Track branch list for this cycle.
Needs: inbox-check

## Step: process-branch
Pick next branch. Rebase on current main.
If rebase conflicts: notify polecat, skip to next branch.
Needs: queue-scan

## Step: run-tests
Run go test ./...
Track results (pass/fail count).
Needs: process-branch

## Step: handle-failures
**GATE**: If tests passed, this step auto-completes.
If tests failed:
- Diagnose: branch regression or pre-existing?
- Branch regression ‚Üí abort, notify polecat
- Pre-existing ‚Üí EITHER fix OR \`bd create --type=bug\`
**VERIFY**: Fix committed OR bead filed before proceeding.
Needs: run-tests

## Step: merge-push
Merge to main (ff-only preferred).
Push immediately.
Delete polecat branch.
Needs: handle-failures

## Step: loop-check
More branches? Return to process-branch.
Otherwise continue to summary.
Needs: merge-push

## Step: generate-summary
Summarize cycle: branches processed, tests results, issues filed.
Needs: loop-check

## Step: context-check
Check context usage.
If high: write handoff, prepare for burn/respawn.
Needs: generate-summary

## Step: burn-or-loop
If context LOW and queue non-empty: loop (return to queue-scan)
If context HIGH or queue empty: burn and exit
Needs: context-check
```

## Implementation Tasks

### 1. Add RefineryPatrolMolecule() to builtin_molecules.go
- Copy pattern from DeaconPatrolMolecule
- Include all steps with proper `Needs:` dependencies
- Emphasize handle-failures gate in description

### 2. Update Refinery CLAUDE.md
Add sections:
- **The Engineer Mindset** (identity/philosophy)
- **The Scotty Test** (Would Scotty walk past this?)
- **Patrol Molecule** reference (mol-refinery-patrol)
- **Test Failure Protocol** (explicit decision tree)

### 3. Create prompts/roles/refinery.md
- Follow pattern of deacon.md
- Include patrol execution loop diagram
- Reference the molecule

### 4. Consider mol-witness-patrol
- Witness has detailed heartbeat protocol but no formal molecule
- Similar pattern could apply

## Why This Matters

GUPP: 'If you have work on your hook, you have to run it.'
The patrol molecule puts failure handling ON THE HOOK as a mandatory step.
You can't skip handle-failures to get to merge-push.
The structure enforces good behavior.

## Related

- docs/molecular-chemistry.md (chemistry concepts)

title: Dynamic wisp modification: insert, reorder, bond mid-execution
description:
## Vision

Wisps should be living documents that adapt mid-execution, not static scripts.

## Operations Needed

### bd mol insert
Insert a step into a running wisp:
```bash
bd mol insert <wisp-id> --after <step> --step 'security-gate: Review auth changes'
```

### bd mol reorder  
Change step order in a running wisp:
```bash
bd mol reorder <wisp-id> --move process-branch --before current
```

### bd mol bond (to wisp)
Attach an entire molecule to a running wisp:
```bash
bd mol bond mol-weekly-maintenance <wisp-id> --after await-work
```

### bd mol skip
Skip a step (with reason):
```bash
bd mol skip <wisp-id> <step> --reason 'Queue empty, skipping summary'
```

## Use Cases

1. **Hotfix priority**: Reorder queue to process urgent MR first
2. **Security gate**: Insert review step when PR touches sensitive files
3. **Scheduled maintenance**: Bond maintenance mol on schedule
4. **Context adaptation**: Skip steps when they don't apply

## Why This Matters

Engine room problems emerge dynamically. The wisp's flexibility lets agents model situations as they evolve, not execute rigid scripts.

GUPP still applies: whatever's on your hook, you run. But the hook contents can adapt.

## Implementation

This requires Beads changes to support wisp mutation:
- Track step ordering in wisp storage
- Support step insertion/deletion/reordering
- Handle bond-to-wisp (spawn steps into existing wisp)
- Preserve audit trail of modifications

title: Ephemeral polecats: spawn fresh, delete on completion
description:
## Design Decision

Switch from pooled/idle polecats to ephemeral model:
- Spawn creates fresh worktree from main
- Polecat requests shutdown when done (bottom-up)
- Witness verifies handoff, kills session, deletes worktree
- No 'idle' state - polecats exist only while working

## Rationale

1. **Git worktrees are fast** - pooling optimization is obsolete
2. **Pooling creates maintenance burden:**
   - Git stashes accumulate
   - Untracked artifacts pile up
   - Branches drift from main
   - Beads DB gets stale
3. **PGT sync problems** came from persistent branches
4. **Support infrastructure exists** - Witness, Refinery, Mayor handle continuity
5. **Simpler mental model** - polecat exists = work in progress

## Lifecycle

```
Spawn:
  gt spawn --issue <id>
  ‚Üí Creates fresh worktree: git worktree add polecats/<name> -b polecat/<name>
  ‚Üí Initializes beads in worktree
  ‚Üí Starts session, assigns work

Working:
  Polecat does task
  ‚Üí Pushes to polecat/<name> branch
  ‚Üí Submits to merge queue when ready

Completion (POLECAT-INITIATED):
  Polecat runs: gt handoff
  ‚Üí Verifies git state clean
  ‚Üí Sends mail to Witness: "Ready for shutdown"
  ‚Üí Marks itself done, waits for termination

Cleanup (WITNESS-OWNED):
  Witness receives shutdown request
  ‚Üí Verifies PR merged or in queue
  ‚Üí Verifies no uncommitted changes
  ‚Üí Kills session: gt session stop <rig>/<polecat>
  ‚Üí Deletes worktree: git worktree remove polecats/<name>
  ‚Üí Deletes branch: git branch -d polecat/<name>
  ‚Üí Optionally: Notifies Mayor of completion
```

## Key Insight: Bottom-Up Shutdown

**Old model (wrong)**: Top-down batch shutdown - "cancel the swarm"
**New model (right)**: Bottom-up individual shutdown - polecat requests, Witness executes

This enables streaming:
- Workers come and go continuously
- No "swarm end" to trigger cleanup
- Each worker manages its own lifecycle
- Witness is the lifecycle authority

## Implementation

1. Add `gt handoff` command for polecats to request shutdown
2. Modify gt spawn to always create fresh worktree
3. Run bd init in new worktree (beads needs initialization)
4. Add shutdown request handler to Witness
5. Witness verifies handoff, then cleans up:
   - Kill session
   - Remove worktree
   - Delete branch
6. Remove 'idle' state from polecat state machine
7. Simplify gt polecat list (only shows active)

## Impact on Other Tasks

- gt-17r (Zombie cleanup): Becomes trivial - orphan worktrees
- gt-4my (Worker health): Simpler - no idle/stuck ambiguity
- gt-f9x.5/f9x.6 (Doctor): Fewer states to validate
- gt-eu9 (Witness handoff): Witness receives polecat shutdown requests

title: gt mail send should tmux-notify recipient
description:
## Problem

When mail is sent via gt mail send, the recipient session does not get a tmux notification. In Python Gas Town (PGT), mail delivery triggers a tmux display-message or similar notification so the agent knows mail arrived.

## Expected Behavior

When gt mail send <addr> is called:
1. Mail is delivered to recipient inbox
2. If recipient has an active tmux session, send notification
3. Notification should be visible (display-message or bell)

## Current Behavior

Mail is delivered but no notification. Agent has to poll inbox to discover new mail.

## Impact

- Agents miss time-sensitive messages
- Heartbeat pokes from daemon will not wake agents
- Coordination is slower (polling vs push)

## Implementation Notes

After successful mail delivery, check if recipient has active session:
- gt session list can identify active sessions
- tmux display-message or send-keys can notify
- Could inject a visible prompt like "[MAIL] New message from <sender>"

## Reference

Check PGT implementation for how it handles this.

title: Session pre-shutdown checks
gt mail: Cross-level routing is broken
description:
**Problem:**
When Mayor (at ~/gt) sends mail to a rig worker (gastown/crew/max), the message lands in town-level beads (~/.beads/) but the recipient checks rig-level beads (crew/max/.beads/).

**Reproduction:**
```bash
cd ~/gt
gt mail send gastown/crew/max -s 'Test' -m 'body'
# Message goes to ~/gt/.beads/ with prefix hq-*

cd ~/gt/gastown/crew/max  
gt mail inbox
# Does NOT see the message - it's looking in crew/max/.beads/
```

**Root cause:**
`findBeadsWorkDir()` walks up from CWD to find .beads. `Router.Send()` runs `bd create` in that directory. This means messages always go to the sender's beads, not the recipient's.

**Fix options:**
1. Route based on recipient address - if sending to rig/*, use that rig's .beads
2. Use a single shared beads database for all mail (simpler but less isolated)
3. Teach agents to check both levels (workaround, not fix)

**Related:**
- gt-ngu1: Pinned beads sorting (done but pointless if mail doesn't route)
- This blocks all cross-level mail functionality

Design and implement a lightweight pattern for firing off single workers to handle tasks without full swarm overhead.

- Swarms (sw-*): Full lifecycle tracking with manifest, state, events, reports
- Ephemeral rigs (rig-*): Temporary worker groups for swarms

## Design Questions

1. Should this be a new command like 'gt fire' or an option on existing commands?
2. Should single tasks still get swarm IDs (sw-N) for consistency/queryability?
3. Should it default to creating new workers or support --reuse for idle polecats?
4. How does this relate to crew workers (gt-cik)?

2. check-refinery - Ensure MQ is alive and processing

- assess - Categorize state (working/idle/error/done)

- decide - Apply nudge matrix
- execute - Take action (nudge/kill/escalate/none)

- Persistent state: witness handoff bead (nudge counts, etc.)
- Digests: Squashed summaries in permanent beads

title: Adaptive backoff for daemon heartbeat
description:
Track agent responsiveness and adjust heartbeat frequency.

## Per-Agent State

```go
type AgentBackoff struct {
    BaseInterval    time.Duration  // 60s default
    CurrentInterval time.Duration  // grows when busy
    MaxInterval     time.Duration  // 10min cap
    ConsecutiveMiss int            // pokes with no response
}
```

## Strategy Options

- **Fixed**: Always 60s (current, simple)
- **Geometric**: 60s ‚Üí 90s ‚Üí 135s ‚Üí 202s (factor 1.5)
- **Exponential**: 60s ‚Üí 120s ‚Üí 240s (factor 2, aggressive)

## Recovery

When agent responds (runs a command):
- Reset ConsecutiveMiss to 0
- Return to BaseInterval immediately

## Benefits

- Reduces noise for busy agents
- Saves resources during quiet periods
- Still catches stuck agents (max interval cap)

title: Add role-specific subcommands that delegate to core commands (agent UX)
description:
## Problem

Agents naturally guess command patterns like:
- `gt witness nudge <polecat>`
- `gt polecat nudge <name>`
- `gt crew restart <member>`

But these don't exist - the actual commands are:
- `gt nudge <session> <message>`
- `gt polecat reset <name>`

This creates friction in agent UX. Agents shouldn't have to memorize the 'correct' command structure.

## Proposal

Add subcommands to each role that delegate to core commands with argument reordering:

```
gt witness nudge furiosa "Start working"
  ‚Üí gt nudge gt-gastown-furiosa "Start working"

gt polecat nudge gastown/furiosa "Check mail"
  ‚Üí gt nudge gt-gastown-furiosa "Check mail"

gt crew nudge gastown/max "Wake up"
  ‚Üí gt nudge gt-crew-gastown-max "Wake up"
```

## Benefits

1. **Discoverable**: Agents explore `gt witness --help` and find nudge
2. **Lenient**: Multiple valid ways to express the same intent
3. **Role-contextual**: Commands under the role namespace feel natural
4. **Extensible**: Pattern works for future subcommands (status, reset, etc.)

## Implementation

Each role command (witness, polecat, crew, refinery) gets thin wrapper subcommands:

```go
// In witness.go
witnessCmd.AddCommand(&cobra.Command{
    Use:   "nudge <polecat> <message>",
    Short: "Nudge a polecat (delegates to gt nudge)",
    RunE: func(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) error {
        session := formatSession(rig, args[0])
        return runNudge(session, args[1])
    },
})
```

## Future Candidates

Other subcommands to add as role-specific aliases:
- `gt polecat status <name>` (already exists, good pattern)
- `gt witness check <polecat>` ‚Üí trigger a manual check
- `gt refinery merge <mr-id>` ‚Üí process specific MR
- `gt crew send <member> <message>` ‚Üí mail to crew member

args = append(args, "--priority", fmt.Sprintf("%d", beadsPriority))
```

2. Change router to only use `--urgent` when priority=0

- `--thread-id` flag (line 51) - bd mail send doesn't have this  
- `--reply-to` flag (line 56) - bd mail send doesn't have this

The router assumes bd mail send has features it doesn't have.

title: Town Doctor molecule for harness health checks
description:
Create a Town Doctor molecule that any Gas Town agent can run to diagnose and repair harness issues.

## Concept

Instead of just `gt doctor` as a CLI command with hardcoded checks, create a **molecule** (checklist workflow) that:
- Any agent (Mayor, Witness, Polecat) can instantiate
- Walks the agent through diagnostic steps
- Agent uses judgment to fix issues found
- Works as a structured troubleshooting guide

## Why a Molecule?

1. **Agent-driven**: The agent running it becomes "the doctor" temporarily
2. **Extensible**: Add new checks by updating the molecule, not code
3. **Contextual**: Agent can reason about issues, not just run scripts
4. **Self-healing**: Agent can fix problems it finds, not just report them

## Proposed Checks (molecule steps)

1. Verify harness structure (mayor/, .beads/, CLAUDE.md exist)
2. Validate config files (town.json, rigs.json parse correctly)
3. Check beads health (bd doctor, redirect validity)
4. Verify git state (clean working tree, proper remotes)
5. Check rig integrity (each registered rig exists, has config.json)
6. Validate agent clones (mayor/rig/, refinery/rig/ exist and are valid)
7. Check for orphaned worktrees/branches
8. Verify daemon state (if running)

## Integration

- `gt doctor` could instantiate the molecule for the current agent
- Or agent can run `bd ready` and pick up doctor tasks when prioritized
- Results logged to beads for audit trail

## Related

- gt-cr9: Harness Design & Documentation (completed)
- Molecules design in architecture.md

title: Molecule Algebra: Work Composition DSL
description:
Implement the molecule algebra - a declarative language for composing, transforming, and executing structured work. Enables mechanical composition without AI.

The Three Phases: Rig ‚Üí Cook ‚Üí Run

- **Rig**: Source-level composition (formula YAML with extends/compose)
- **Cook**: Instantiation (formula ‚Üí proto ‚Üí mol/wisp)
- **Run**: Execution (agents complete steps)

Two Composition Operators:
- **Rig** operates on formulas (source level)
- **Bond** operates on artifacts (protos, mols, wisps)

Key components:
- Formulas: YAML source with composition rules (.formula.yaml)
- Cook: Pre-expand macros/aspects to flat proto
- Phase verbs (pour, wisp)
- Bond: Artifact-level polymorphic composition
- Composition operators (sequence, parallel, branch, loop, gate)
- Advice operators (before, after, around - Lisp style)
- Expansion operators (macros like Rule of Five)
- Aspects (AOP cross-cutting concerns)

See docs/rig-cook-run.md for the lifecycle spec.
See docs/molecule-algebra.md for full algebra specification.
Example formulas in .beads/formulas/

title: gt daemon: Background service management
description:
## Summary

ONE daemon for all Gas Town - a simple Go process (not a Claude agent) that:
1. Pokes agents periodically (heartbeat)
2. Processes lifecycle requests
3. Restarts sessions when agents request cycling

## Architecture

Daemon (gt daemon)
- Pokes Mayor: "HEARTBEAT: check your rigs"
- Pokes each Witness: "HEARTBEAT: check your workers"
- Has inbox at daemon/ for lifecycle requests
- Restarts sessions on cycle requests

## NOT the daemon's job:
- Making decisions (Witnesses do that)
- Running Claude (it's a Go process)
- Processing work (polecats do that)
- Direct polecat management (Witnesses do that)

The daemon is a **dumb scheduler** - poke things, execute lifecycle requests. All intelligence is in agents.

## Commands

- gt daemon start: Start daemon (background)
- gt daemon stop: Stop daemon
- gt daemon status: Show daemon status
- gt daemon logs: View daemon logs

## Daemon Loop

Every heartbeat interval:
1. Poke Mayor
2. For each rig: Poke Witness
3. Process lifecycle requests from daemon/ inbox
4. Check for dead sessions, restart if cycle requested

## Lifecycle Request Handling

Daemon checks its inbox (daemon/) for lifecycle requests:
- From Mayor: cycle/restart Mayor session
- From Witnesses: cycle/restart Witness session

On request:
1. Verify agent state shows requesting_cycle
2. Kill session
3. Start new session
4. Clear requesting_cycle flag

## Poke Protocol

Poke = tmux inject "HEARTBEAT: do your job"
- Agent ignores if already working
- Agent wakes up if idle
- Idempotent - multiple pokes are fine

## Lifecycle Hierarchy

- Daemon manages: Mayor, all Witnesses
- Witness manages: Polecats, Refinery (per rig)
- Crew: self-managed (human workspace)

## Related Issues

- gt-kmn.11: Daemon heartbeat details
- gt-gby: gt handoff command (unified lifecycle)
- gt-u1j.9: Fold witness daemon into this

title: Federation: Wasteland architecture for cross-town coordination
description:
## Overview

Federation enables Gas Town to scale across machines via **Outposts** - remote compute environments that can run workers.

**Design doc**: docs/federation-design.md

## Outpost Types

| Type | Description | Cost Model |
|------|-------------|------------|
| Local | Current model (tmux panes) | Free |
| SSH/VM | Full Gas Town clone on VM | Always-on |
| CloudRun | Container workers on GCP | Pay-per-use |

## Key Concepts

### Outpost Abstraction
```go
type Outpost interface {
    Name() string
    Type() OutpostType  // local, ssh, cloudrun
    MaxWorkers() int
    Spawn(issue string, config WorkerConfig) (Worker, error)
    Workers() []Worker
    Ping() error
}
```

### Cloud Run Workers
- Persistent HTTP/2 connections solve zero-to-one cold start
- Pay only when working (~$0.017 per 5-min session)
- Scale 0‚ÜíN automatically
- Git clone via persistent volumes

### SSH/VM Outposts  
- Full Gas Town clone on remote machine
- SSH for commands, git for sync
- Good for long-running autonomous work

## Design Principles

1. **Outpost abstraction** - support multiple backends
2. **Local-first** - remote is for overflow/burst
3. **Git as source of truth** - code and beads sync everywhere
4. **HTTP for Cloud Run** - dont force mail onto containers
5. **Graceful degradation** - works with any subset of outposts

## Related

CloudRun cost tracking: Usage monitoring and limits
description:
## Overview

Track Cloud Run usage costs and enforce spending limits.

## Cost Model

Cloud Run pricing (approximate):
- CPU: ~$0.000024/vCPU-second
- Memory: ~$0.0000025/GiB-second
- Requests: ~$0.40/million

For 5-minute worker (2 vCPU, 4GB):
- CPU: 300 √ó 2 √ó $0.000024 = $0.0144
- Memory: 300 √ó 4 √ó $0.0000025 = $0.003
- **Total: ~$0.017 per session**

## Implementation

```go
type CostTracker struct {
    cpuRate    float64  // per vCPU-second
    memRate    float64  // per GiB-second
    sessions   []SessionCost
    mu         sync.RWMutex
}

type SessionCost struct {
    WorkerID  string
    StartTime time.Time
    EndTime   time.Time
    CPUs      float64
    MemoryGiB float64
}

func (t *CostTracker) RecordSession(workerID string, start, end time.Time, cpus, mem float64) {
    t.mu.Lock()
    defer t.mu.Unlock()
    t.sessions = append(t.sessions, SessionCost{...})
}

func (t *CostTracker) CurrentCost() float64 {
    t.mu.RLock()
    defer t.mu.RUnlock()
    var total float64
    for _, s := range t.sessions {
        duration := s.EndTime.Sub(s.StartTime).Seconds()
        total += duration * s.CPUs * t.cpuRate
        total += duration * s.MemoryGiB * t.memRate
    }
    return total
}
```

## Cost Cap Enforcement

```go
func (o *CloudRunOutpost) Spawn(...) (Worker, error) {
    if o.costCap > 0 && o.costTracker.CurrentCost() >= o.costCap {
        return nil, ErrCostCapExceeded
    }
    // ... spawn worker
}
```

## Config

```yaml
outposts:
  - name: cloudrun-burst
    type: cloudrun
    cost_cap_hourly: 5.00   # Stop spawning if hourly cost exceeds $5
    cost_cap_daily: 50.00   # Daily limit
```

## CLI

```bash
gt outpost status cloudrun-burst
# Shows: Cost (today): $0.42 / $50.00 cap
```

## Files

- `internal/cloudrun/cost.go`

## Dependencies

title: CloudRunOutpost: Basic implementation
description:
## Overview

Basic CloudRunOutpost implementation. Persistent connections and cost tracking are separate tasks.

## Implementation

```go
type CloudRunOutpost struct {
    name        string
    project     string
    region      string
    service     string
    maxWorkers  int
    client      *WorkClient
    workers     map[string]*CloudRunWorker
    mu          sync.RWMutex
}

func NewCloudRunOutpost(cfg OutpostConfig) (*CloudRunOutpost, error) {
    serviceURL := fmt.Sprintf(
        "https://%s-%s.a.run.app",
        cfg.Service, cfg.Region,
    )
    return &CloudRunOutpost{
        name:       cfg.Name,
        project:    cfg.Project,
        region:     cfg.Region,
        service:    cfg.Service,
        maxWorkers: cfg.MaxWorkers,
        client:     NewWorkClient(serviceURL),
        workers:    make(map[string]*CloudRunWorker),
    }, nil
}
```

## Spawn

```go
func (o *CloudRunOutpost) Spawn(issue string, cfg WorkerConfig) (Worker, error) {
    req := WorkRequest{
        IssueID: issue,
        Rig:     RigConfig{URL: cfg.RigURL, Branch: cfg.GitBranch},
        Beads:   BeadsConfig{URL: cfg.BeadsURL, Branch: "beads-sync"},
        Branch:  "polecat/" + issue,
    }
    
    events, err := o.client.DispatchWork(context.Background(), req)
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    
    worker := &CloudRunWorker{
        id:      uuid.New().String(),
        outpost: o.name,
        issue:   issue,
        events:  events,
        status:  WorkerStatusWorking,
    }
    
    o.mu.Lock()
    o.workers[worker.id] = worker
    o.mu.Unlock()
    
    go worker.monitor()
    return worker, nil
}
```

## CloudRunWorker

```go
type CloudRunWorker struct {
    id      string
    outpost string
    issue   string
    status  WorkerStatus
    events  <-chan WorkEvent
    logs    []string
}

func (w *CloudRunWorker) Attach() error {
    return errors.New("Cloud Run workers do not support attach")
}

func (w *CloudRunWorker) Logs() (io.Reader, error) {
    return strings.NewReader(strings.Join(w.logs, "\n")), nil
}
```

Polecat wisp architecture: Proto ‚Üí Wisp ‚Üí Mol pattern
description:
Design the three-layer architecture for polecat lifecycle:

## The Insight

Polecats should run a ONE-SHOT WISP (not looping like patrols):

**Step 1: Onboard**
- Read full polecat protocol (polecat.md template)
- Learn Gas Town operation, exit strategies, molecule protocol
- This is the 'how to be a polecat' education

**Step 2: Execute Mol**
- Run the assigned molecule (the actual work item)
- Could span multiple sessions via session continuity
- The mol is pure work content (epic, issue, feature)

**Step 3: Cleanup**
- Run final step of the wisp
- Self-delete / request shutdown

## Three Layers

- **Proto**: polecat.md template (instructions for being a polecat)
- **Wisp**: One-shot harness instantiated from proto (wraps the mol)
- **Mol**: The work item (issue/epic being processed)

## Why This Matters

1. **Separation of concerns**: Protocol (how) vs Work (what)
2. **Reusability**: Same wisp harness wraps any mol
3. **Extensibility**: Plugin points for custom behavior
4. **Session continuity**: Wisp handles multi-session, not the mol
5. **Blurred control/data planes**: Intentional in Gas Town

## Design Questions

1. How does proto (polecat.md) become a wisp instance?
2. What are the plugin/extension points?
3. Should all 'engineer in a box' mols use proto ‚Üí wisp ‚Üí mol?
4. How does this relate to refinery/deacon patterns?

title: gt spawn should create fresh polecat worktree, never reuse
description:
Currently gt spawn tries to reuse existing polecats, which causes:

1. Stale beads database
2. Stale code (behind main/integration)
3. Old inbox messages
4. Git history pollution

## Current Behavior

gt spawn:
1. Looks for idle polecat in pool
2. If found, reuses existing worktree
3. Assigns new issue

## Desired Behavior

gt spawn:
1. Always create FRESH polecat from current main/integration
2. Fresh worktree with clean beads
3. No reuse of old worktrees

## Name Pool Still Useful

Keep name pool for:
- Allocating themed names (mad-max, etc.)
- Tracking which names are in use

But worktrees should be created fresh each time.

## Implementation

In spawn.go, before starting work:
1. If worktree exists: remove it first
2. Create fresh worktree from integration branch
3. Sync beads from rig to polecat
4. Then proceed with work assignment

This ensures polecats always start with latest code and beads.

title: Mol Mall: Molecule marketplace distribution
description:
Design the Mol Mall distribution mechanism for sharing molecules.

## Core Insight

Mol Mall is just a registry of molecules.jsonl fragments. No special format needed.

## Distribution Model

```
Mol Mall (registry)
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îÇ bd mol search "security"
    ‚ñº
Molecule catalog (searchable index)
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îÇ bd mol install mol-security-scan
    ‚ñº
Download molecules.jsonl fragment
    ‚îÇ
    ‚îÇ Append to ~/.beads/molecules.jsonl
    ‚ñº
Available locally: bd mol list
```

## Registry Format

Simple JSON index served from HTTPS:

```json
{
  "molecules": [
    {
      "id": "mol-security-scan",
      "title": "Security Scan",
      "description": "OWASP Top 10 vulnerability checker",
      "labels": ["plugin", "code-review", "tier:sonnet"],
      "author": "anthropic",
      "version": "1.0.0",
      "url": "https://mol-mall.anthropic.com/molecules/mol-security-scan.jsonl"
    }
  ]
}
```

## CLI Commands

```bash
bd mol search <query>           # Search registry
bd mol info <id>                # Show molecule details
bd mol install <id>             # Download and install
bd mol uninstall <id>           # Remove from catalog
bd mol update                   # Update all installed molecules
```

## Installation Locations

```
~/.beads/molecules.jsonl        # User-level (default install location)
~/gt/.beads/molecules.jsonl     # Town-level (shared across rigs)
.beads/molecules.jsonl          # Project-level (team-specific)
```

## Version Management

Molecules can have versions via labels: `version:1.0.0`
Install specific version: `bd mol install mol-security-scan@1.0.0`

## Auth (Future)

Private registries could require auth token.
Enterprise Mol Malls for internal distribution.

2. Execute current step
3. Update step status via bd mol step
4. Generate summary when all steps complete
5. Run bd mol squash to compress wisp into digest

### Key Commands
- bd mol show <wisp-id> - view current molecule state
- bd mol step <wisp-id> --status=complete - mark step done
- bd mol squash <wisp-id> --summary='...' - complete molecule

### Summary Generation
When completing work, generate a summary that:
- Lists what was accomplished
- Notes any deviations from the plan
- Captures key decisions made
- This becomes the permanent digest

title: File locking for concurrent access
description:
Add file locking for concurrent access safety.

## At-Risk Files
- .gastown/swarms.json (or per-swarm state.json)
- .gastown/refinery.json
- polecats/<name>/state.json
- inbox.jsonl files

## Go File Locking
Use syscall.Flock for advisory locking:
```go
type FileLock struct {
    file *os.File
}

func AcquireLock(path string, timeout time.Duration) (*FileLock, error) {
    f, err := os.OpenFile(path+".lock", os.O_CREATE|os.O_RDWR, 0644)
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    // Use syscall.Flock with timeout
}

func (l *FileLock) Release() error
```

## Integration Pattern
```go
func (m *Manager) saveState(ref *Refinery) error {
    lock, err := AcquireLock(m.stateFile(), 5*time.Second)
    if err != nil {
        return fmt.Errorf("could not acquire lock: %w", err)
    }
    defer lock.Release()
    
    // Read-modify-write cycle
}
```

## New Package
internal/filelock/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ lock.go     # FileLock, AcquireLock
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ lock_test.go

## Apply To
- internal/refinery/manager.go: loadState/saveState
- internal/cmd/swarm.go: SwarmStore
- internal/mail/mailbox.go: Append, rewrite
- internal/polecat/manager.go: state operations

## Timeout Handling
Default 5 second timeout. Return error if lock not acquired.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Timeout on lock contention
- [ ] All state files protected
- [ ] Locks released on error paths

title: gt sling: use mail queue for patrol roles (witness, refinery, deacon)
description:
When slinging work to patrol agents, queue via mail instead of replacing hook.

**Rationale:**
Patrol agents run continuous loops. Replacing their hook with discrete work breaks patrol continuity - when the task completes, the patrol stops.

**New behavior for patrol roles (witness, refinery, deacon):**
1. Check if patrol is running (hook has patrol molecule attached)
2. If patrol running:
   - Don't touch hook (patrol stays pinned)
   - Send work assignment mail
   - Print 'Queued for next patrol cycle'
3. If patrol NOT running:
   - Start default patrol for that role (mol-witness-patrol, mol-refinery-patrol, mol-deacon-patrol)
   - Send work assignment mail
   - Print 'Started patrol and queued work'

**New flags:**
- --urgent: Interrupt current patrol cycle, process this work immediately
- --replace: Explicitly terminate patrol and pin discrete work (break-glass)

**No change for:**
- Polecat, Crew, Mayor (discrete task agents - current behavior)

**Dependencies:**
- Patrol templates must have 'check inbox' step (verify/add)
- Need to know default patrol molecule for each role

title: BUG: gt done doesn't push branch to origin - work lost when worktree deleted
description:
## Problem

`gt done` creates a merge-request record in beads but **never pushes the branch to origin**.

When polecats are cleaned up (worktrees deleted), the branch is lost forever. The MR record exists but there's no actual branch to merge.

## Evidence

12 MQ items had `ready` status but no corresponding branches on origin. All polecat worktrees were deleted, losing all work.

## Impact

**CRITICAL**: All polecat work is silently lost unless polecats manually push (which they don't know to do).

## Fix

In `done.go`, before creating the MR:
1. `git push origin <branch>` to push the branch to remote
2. Only create MR record if push succeeds

## Location
`mayor/rig/internal/cmd/done.go:124-135`

title: Beads as Universal Data Plane
description:
## Vision

Beads is the data plane for all Gas Town operations. Everything flows through beads:
- Work items (issues, tasks, epics)
- Mail (messages between agents)
- Merge requests (queue entries)
- Workflows (composable execution patterns)
- Resources (leases, locks, quotas)
- Schedules (timed activities)

## New Bead Categories

### Molecules (Composable Workflows)
Crystallized workflow patterns that can be attached to work items.

### Timed Beads (Scheduled Work)
Beads that wake up periodically via daemon.

### Pinned Beads (Ongoing Concerns)
Beads representing persistent concerns, not discrete tasks.

### Resource Beads (Leases/Locks)
Beads representing reserved resources.

## v1 Priority

- **P0**: Molecules (enables engineer-in-box)
- **P2**: Timed, Pinned, Resource beads (post-v1)

title: Auto-handoff: self-cycling with guaranteed work pickup
description:
## Summary

A mechanism for agents to self-cycle: send handoff mail, request Deacon to kill the process, and automatically restart to pick up the work.

## Use Case

User says: `auto-handoff: gt-bug3`

The agent:
1. Sends handoff mail documenting current state
2. Requests Deacon to terminate the session
3. Deacon restarts the agent in background
4. New session picks up the handoff and continues working

When the user returns to terminal, the old session is gone but work continues in background. User can reattach.

## Key Requirements

- **Guaranteed pickup**: Something in the hook and/or handoff must ensure the new session picks up the work (not just a passive "check inbox")
- **Background execution**: Work continues without user presence
- **Reattachability**: User can reconnect to see progress

## Design Questions

1. Can molecules help coordinate this? (e.g., molecule binds the handoff + auto-restart)
2. What hook handles the pickup guarantee? 
3. How does Deacon know to restart vs just kill?
4. How does user reattach to a background agent?

## Related

- Molecules system
- Deacon lifecycle management
- Handoff hooks

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---

title: mol-gastown-boot
description:
Mayor bootstraps Gas Town via a verification-gated lifecycle molecule.

## Purpose
When Mayor executes "boot up gas town", this proto provides the workflow.
Each step has action + verification - steps stay open until outcome is confirmed.

## Key Principles
1. **Verification-gated steps** - Not "command ran" but "outcome confirmed"
2. **gt peek for verification** - Capture session output to detect stalls
3. **gt nudge for recovery** - Reliable message delivery to unstick agents
4. **Parallel where possible** - Witnesses and refineries can start in parallel
5. **Ephemeral execution** - Boot is a wisp, squashed to digest after completion

## Step Structure
Each step has Action/Verify/OnStall/OnFail sections.

## Execution
```bash
bd mol spawn mol-gastown-boot  # Create wisp
bd mol run <wisp-id>           # Execute
```

title: Witness handoff bead state persistence
description:
Implement state persistence for Witness across wisp cycles.

## Problem
Wisps burn between cycles, but Witness needs to remember:
- Which workers have been nudged
- How many times (nudge_count)
- When was last nudge
- Last observed activity

## Solution
Witness handoff bead with worker_states field:

```json
{
  "id": "gt-witness-state",
  "type": "handoff",
  "assignee": "<rig>/witness",
  "pinned": true,
  "worker_states": {
    "furiosa": {
      "issue": "gt-123",
      "nudge_count": 2,
      "last_nudge": "2024-12-22T10:00:00Z"
    }
  },
  "last_patrol": "2024-12-22T10:05:00Z"
}
```

## Implementation
1. On patrol start: bd show <witness-handoff-id> to load state
2. During patrol: update in-memory state
3. On save-state step: bd update to persist
4. State survives wisp burn/squash

title: Timed Beads: Scheduled recurring work
description:
## Summary

Timed beads wake up periodically and get injected into the ready queue by the daemon.

## Schema Extension

```yaml
id: gt-weekly-sync
type: task  # or sentinel
schedule: "0 9 * * 1"  # cron: Monday 9am
# OR
interval: 24h          # every 24 hours
tier: haiku            # cheap model for routine checks
next_run: 2025-12-20T09:00:00Z
```

## Daemon Integration

Daemon heartbeat loop:
1. Check timed beads where `next_run <= now`
2. For each due bead:
   - Inject into ready queue (set status to open if needed)
   - Update `next_run` based on schedule/interval
3. Witnesses pick up work via `bd ready`

## Use Cases

- Weekly team sync reminders
- Daily health checks
- Periodic cleanup tasks
- Scheduled reports

## Interaction with Pinned Beads

A pinned bead can be timed - it wakes up periodically but never closes.
This is how you model "background services" in Gas Town.

title: Overseer Crew: User-managed persistent workspaces
description:
## Overview

Crew workers are the overseer's (human's) personal workspaces within a rig. Unlike polecats which are witness-managed and ephemeral, crew workers are:

- **Persistent**: Not auto-garbage-collected
- **User-managed**: Overseer controls lifecycle
- **Long-lived identities**: dave, emma, fred - recognizable names
- **Gas Town integrated**: Mail, handoff mechanics work
- **Tmux optional**: Can work in terminal directly

## Directory Structure

```
<rig>/
  polecats/       # Managed workers (witness controls)
  refinery/       # Merge queue processor
  witness/        # Pit boss
  crew/           # Overseer's personal workspaces
    dave/         # Full clone, persistent
    emma/         # Full clone, persistent
    fred/         # Full clone, persistent
```

## Key Differences from Polecats

- Location: crew/ instead of polecats/
- Lifecycle: User-managed, not witness-managed
- Auto-cleanup: Never (polecats auto-cleanup on swarm land)
- Issue assignment: Optional (polecats require it)
- Tmux: Optional (polecats require it)
- Mail & Handoff: Yes for both
- Identity: Persistent (polecats are ephemeral)

## CLI Commands

- gt crew add <name> [--rig <rig>] - Create crew workspace
- gt crew list [--rig <rig>] - List crew workspaces
- gt crew at <rig>/<name> - Attach to workspace (start session)
- gt crew attach <name> - Attach (infer rig from cwd)
- gt crew refresh <name> - Handoff + restart (context cycling)
- gt crew remove <name> [--force] - Remove workspace
- gt crew status [<name>] - Show workspace status

## Design Notes

- Crew workers use full git clones (not worktrees)
- Optional beads integration via BEADS_DIR
- Mail-to-self handoff works for context cycling
- No witness monitoring or nudging
- No automatic issue assignment required

## Background

Users often maintain separate repo clones for serial agent work. This is tedious to set up manually. Crew workspaces bring these into Gas Town's infrastructure while keeping user control.

title: Implement handoffs using pinned beads
description:
Replace the current mail-based handoff system with pinned beads.

## Current Problem

Handoff messages get closed before the successor can read them because:
1. `gt mail read` auto-acks (closes) messages
2. `bd mail inbox` only shows open messages
3. Successor sees empty inbox

## Solution

Use pinned beads for handoffs:
- One pinned bead per role: `mayor-handoff`, `<rig>-refinery-handoff`, etc.
- Predecessor updates the content before cycling
- Successor reads on startup via `gt prime`
- Never closes - always available

## Implementation

### 1. Create handoff beads on first cycle
- `bd create --title='Mayor Handoff' --type=task --status=pinned --assignee=mayor`
- Store ID in role config or use well-known naming convention

### 2. Update gt handoff command
- Instead of `bd mail send`, update the pinned handoff bead
- `bd update <handoff-id> --description='...handoff content...'`

### 3. Update gt prime
- Read the role's handoff bead
- Display content to successor

### 4. Compression/reset
- `gt rig reset` clears handoff content
- Or manual: `bd update <handoff-id> --description=''`

## Dependencies

Requires beads-6v2 (StatusPinned) to be implemented first.

title: Haiku-based smart stuck detection
description:
Use Haiku to analyze tmux state when signals are ambiguous.

## When to Invoke

Only as escalation tier:
1. Keepalive is stale (> 2 min)
2. Tmux shows claude is running (not idle shell)
3. Heuristics can't determine state

## Prompt

Capture last 50 lines of tmux pane, ask Haiku:
'Is this Claude agent: WORKING | STUCK | IDLE | WAITING_FOR_HUMAN?'

## Cost

~$0.001 per check. At 1 check/min worst case = $0.06/hour.
In practice, most checks avoided by keepalive signal.

## Configuration

```toml
[daemon]
smart_detection = true
smart_model = "haiku"
smart_threshold = "2m"  # only check if stale > 2min
```

title: mol-polecat-arm
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Steps

### capture
Capture recent tmux output for this polecat.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-{{rig}}-{{polecat_name}} -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

### assess
Categorize polecat state.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

### load-history
Read nudge history for this polecat from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[{{polecat_name}}].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[{{polecat_name}}].timestamp
```

Needs: assess

### decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

### execute
Take the decided action.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-{{rig}}-{{polecat_name}} "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/{{polecat_name}}
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: {{polecat_name}} stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp

This data feeds back to the patrol's aggregate step.

## Beads Access Section for Prompting

```markdown
## Beads Access

You have **full beads access** - create, update, and close issues.

### Quick Reference

```bash
# View work
bd ready                    # Issues ready (no blockers)
bd list                     # All open issues
bd show <id>                # Issue details

# Create issues
bd create --title="Fix bug" --type=bug --priority=2
bd create --title="Add feature" --type=feature

# Update issues
bd update <id> --status=in_progress    # Claim work
bd close <id>                          # Mark complete

# Sync (required before merge!)
bd sync                     # Commit beads changes to git
```

### When to Create Issues

Create beads issues when you discover work that:
- Is outside your current task scope
- Would benefit from tracking
- Should be done by someone else

**Good examples**:
```bash
bd create --title="Race condition in auth" --type=bug --priority=1
bd create --title="Document API rate limits" --type=task --priority=3
```

**Don't create for**:
- Tiny fixes you can do in 2 minutes
- Vague "improvements" with no scope
- Work already tracked elsewhere

### Beads Sync Protocol

**CRITICAL**: Always sync beads before merging!

```bash
bd sync                    # Commits beads changes
git add .beads/
git commit -m "beads: sync"
```

If you forget to sync, beads changes are lost when session ends.
```

## Session Cycling Protocol

```markdown
## Session Cycling

Your context will fill over long swarms. Proactively cycle when:
- Running for many hours
- Losing track of which workers you've checked
- Responses getting slower
- About to start complex operation

### Handoff Protocol

1. **Capture current state**:
```bash
town list .           # Worker states
town all beads        # Pending verifications  
town inbox            # Unprocessed messages
```

2. **Compose handoff note**:
```
[HANDOFF_TYPE]: witness_cycle
[TIMESTAMP]: <now>
[RIG]: <rig>

## Active Workers
<list workers and status>

## Pending Verifications
<workers signaled done but not verified>

## Recent Actions
<last 3-5 actions>

## Warnings/Notes
<anything next session should know>

## Next Steps
<what should happen next>
```

3. **Send handoff**:
```bash
town mail send <rig>/witness -s "Session Handoff" -m "<note>"
```

4. **Exit cleanly**: End session, daemon spawns fresh one.

### On Fresh Session Start

1. Check for handoff: `town inbox | grep "Session Handoff"`
2. If found, read it and resume from handoff state
3. If not found, do full status check
```

Add to WITNESS_CLAUDE.md template.
